results.title: Winning is everything?
results.brief_description: Looks at the intense pressure placed by parents, teachers and coaches on young children in competitive sporting events, at the high drop-out rates in all sports, and at the need to emphasise enjoyment and basic skills acquisition as a foundation for recreation in later life. Suitable for tertiary level.

results.title: Buzz Off
results.brief_description:
This clay-animated story is about respect for others who are different or have different cultures. Overcome by Bees, The Jewel Beetles must flee their home to find a safe place to live. Forced to brave a treacherous river and evade hungry predators, the Jewel Beetles reach the safety of Grasshopper Land. They overhear a debate between two grasshoppers. One grasshopper believes that beetles would bring new perspectives and cultures to Grasshopper Land, while the other grasshopper, fearing change, thinks the beetles don’t belong. Intolerance or acceptance will determine the Jewel Beetles’ fate.
Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Yarraville West Primary School’s 5/6 Film Team were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: 'Screen It' 2011 - Winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2011 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Respect.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2011 Screen It competition!

results.title: Winnie the Pooh discovers the seasons
results.creator_credit: Ennis McNutty, Rick Reinert and Walt Disney
results.brief_description: Christopher Robin gives Winnie the Pooh a calendar to keep track of days and seasons. Winnie and his friends discover the joys of long, warm days and Winnie learns about hibernation from the Wise Owl. With songs and music.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ennis McNutty, Rick Reinert and Walt Disney

results.title: Winnie the Pooh and Tigger too
results.creator_credit: John Lounsbery, Wolfgang Reitherman and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Rambunctious Tigger bounces his way through this film, leaving a trail of laughter and enjoyment behind him. Poor Rabbit, driven to distraction by Tigger’s high spirits plot’s a “calming sort of lesson”.

results.title: Twin Peaks. Season one. Eps 5-7 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mark Frost, Caleb Deschanel, Lesli Glatter, Gregg Fienberg, Frost Productions and Lynch/Frost Productions
results.brief_description: Ep 5: In this episode, Agent Cooper and Sheriff Truman discover several new leads which point to the involvement of Leo Johnson and Jacques Renault in Laura’s murder. Audrey Horne continues to provide more unexpected assistance to the investigation as she infiltrates the nearby brothel, One-Eyed Jacks, in an effort to impress Agent Cooper. Meanwhile, Donna forms a new bond with James Hurley and Madeline, while Laura’s father, Leland Palmer, becomes even more unhinged. Ep 6: Agent Cooper and Big Ed Hurley, James’ uncle, go undercover at the casino and brothel, One-Eyed Jacks, unaware of Audrey’s similar plans. Meanwhile James Hurley and Donna Hayward, suspicious of Laura’s psychiatrist, Dr. Jacoby, decide to lay a trap for him by disguising Madeline as Laura, back from the dead. Ep 7: The final episode of the first season sees the climax of several important plotlines. Donna and James’ trap for Dr. Jacoby backfires after he is beaten and has a heart attack. Agent Cooper’s undercover infiltration of One-Eyed Jacks leads to a telling encounter with Jacques Renault, who confesses to his activities on the night of Laura’s murder. Meanwhile, Leo Johnson sets fire to the mill with his wife inside, unknowing of the plans for his own demise.

results.title: Twin Peaks. Pilot. Season one. Eps 1-4 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tim Hunter, Tina Rathborne, Duwayne Dunham, David Lynch, Gregg Fienberg, Frost Productions and Lynch/Frost Productions
results.brief_description: What happened to Laura Palmer? This became one of pop culture’s most discussed questions when this pilot for David Lynch’s “Twin Peaks” was first aired on television. Kyle MacLachlan plays FBI agent Dale Cooper who comes into the sleepy small-town Twin Peaks to investigate Laura Palmer’s murder and discovers that underneath the banal facade the town hides a labyrinth of perversity and evil. As with “Eraserhead” and “Blue Velvet”, Lynch uses macabre humour to expose the psychological neurosis and psychosis that underlie the supposed normality of middle-class America. Both wickedly funny and savagely shocking, “Twin Peaks” radicalised the potential of the TV mini-series by introducing generic forms and psychological content that had previously been isolated to independent cinema. Ep 1: An autopsy reveals a few unexpected clues relating to Laura’s actions on the night of her murder. Laura’s secret lover James Hurley, is released from custody. Ep 2: Agent Cooper turns to unconventional criminology methods, lecturing the local Sheriff’s office on the wisdom of Tibet. Several important plot threads are also revealed in this episode, while a new and uneasy friendship forms between the sultry and spoilt Audrey Horne and Laura’s best friend, Donna Hayward. This episode, directed by Lynch himself, ends with the much discussed surreal dream sequence where Agent Cooper encounters strange figures such as the One-Armed Man, the Magician, the dancing Man from Another Place and Laura Palmer herself. Ep 3: This episode begins the morning after Agent Cooper’s dream in which Laura Palmer revealed to him the killer’s name. Unfortunately, Agent Cooper has forgotten, and he and Sheriff Truman must continue the investigation with FBI forensic expert, Albert Rosenfeld’s assistance. Meanwhile, the town readies itself for Laura’s funeral and deals with the arrival of Madeline Ferguson, Laura’s dark-haired but otherwise identical cousin. Ep 4: Agent Cooper’s dream visions begin to materialise in this episode as Sarah Palmer, Laura’s mother, has a vision of the evil man named Bob, and Deputy Hawke has located the One-Armed Man. Laura’s classmate, Audrey Horne, has also been looking for clues as she begins to suspect that her father may have some involvement in Laura’s murder. “Twin Peaks” is a soap opera and police drama as reinterpreted by the leading urrealist of contemporary cinema.

results.title: Twin Peaks. Pilot episode
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, David J. Llatt, Frost Productions and Lynch/Frost Productions
results.brief_description: What happened to Laura Palmer? This became one of pop culture’s most discussed questions when this pilot for David Lynch’s “Twin Peaks” was first aired on television. Kyle MacLachlan plays FBI agent Dale Cooper who comes into the sleepy small-town Twin Peaks to investigate Laura Palmer’s murder and discovers that underneath the banal facade the town hides a labyrinth of perversity and evil. As with “Eraserhead” and “Blue Velvet”, Lynch uses macabre humour to expose the psychological neurosis and psychosis that underlie the supposed normality of middle-class America. Both wickedly funny and savagely shocking, “Twin Peaks” radicalised the potential of the TV mini-series by introducing generic forms and psychological content that had previously been isolated to independent cinema. This is the initial pilot episode but it also stands alone as a feature film. “Twin Peaks” is a soap opera and police drama as reinterpreted by the leading surrealist of contemporary cinema.

results.title: Twice dead
results.creator_credit: Bert Dragin, Robert McDonnell, Guy Louthan and Concorde Pictures
results.brief_description: A family learn the grisly cost of their inheritance when the mansion they take possession of proves to be the house from hell. By day they are harassed by a vigilante street gang, by night they are visited by the ghostly apparition of a dead actor. It’s a choice between two evils when both night and day present equally horrific forms of evil. Cast includes Tom Breznahan, Jill Whitlow, Jonathan Chapin and Christopher Burgard.

results.title: TwentyFourSeven = 24 7
results.creator_credit: Shane Meadows, Imogen West, Scala, BBC Film Unit and October Films
results.brief_description: TwentyFourSeven marks the screen debut of writer/director Shane Meadows with an assuredness and humour about working/under class people that is also to be a theme in subsequent films (“A Room for Romeo Brass”). Shot in black and white, the lack of colour adds to the washed-out public housing development in which unemployed families pass the time, time that does nothing to change their situations. Darcy (Bob Hoskins) fondly remembers in his youth that a boxing club gave him some hope, so he sets about combining the local gangs to form a youth club. Moments of humour in the script provide lighter distractions as the weight of the whole film and its import in post-Thatcher’s Britain can sit heavily with viewer. Among the failures and hopelessness, camaraderie and self-respect are not all lost along with demise of the club and Darcy’s descent into alcoholism. Great soundtrack, with a cast that includes: Frank Harper, Karl Collins, Bruce Jones and Danny Nussbaum. Co-written by Paul Fraser.
